awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2021 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. 

The title of the project for this fellowship to Monica A. Lewis is " The closed support problem over positive characteristic singularities". The host institution for the fellowship is University of Minnesota, and the sponsoring scientist is Gennady Lyubeznik.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project's goal was to make progress towards an open conjecture in commutative algebra and algebraic geometry called the "closed support problem" in characteristic p. The main difficulty is the failure of certain classical techniques from what is called "F-module theory" to carry over from the world of smooth spaces to the world of singularities. Our main contribution was the development of a novel class of F-modules that opens new directions on how one might try to bridge this gap.


    Background: A commutative ring is an algebraic object equipped with a notion of addition and multiplication. The algebraic structure of these objects turns out to encode a very rich geometry. A particularly interesting kind of geometry results when the algebra of the ring forces p = 0 for some prime integer p. Such rings are said to have characteristic p. Among their remarkable algebraic properties is the fact that taking pth powers is an additive operation, which is called the Frobenius homomorphism. Many natural objects from characteristic p geometry come equipped with an action of the Frobenius, and it is a theorem of Kunz (1969) that the Frobenius homomorphism can detect singularities. Due to Lyubeznik (1997), there is a robust theory of special Frobenius actions over rings of characteristic p whose geometry is free of singularities. This theory is called "unit F-module theory." Using unit F-modules, one can prove deep geometric theorems, including for certain some otherwise mysterious objects called local cohomology modules. This theory is unavailable over a ring with singularities, and it is a major open problem to find a suitable replacement. Finding such a replacement could resolve several important conjectures in geometry, such as the closed support problem.


    In this project, the PI has found a new class of Frobenius modules over a polynomial ring similar in certain respects to classical objects of study called holonomic D-modules. This class, which we call "F-holonomic," is based on the growth of certain monomial counting functions. We prove that, for a wide class of F-modules, the Hilbert series of these monomial counting functions is a rational function. We have proved that two numerical quantities read off from the Hilbert series, which we call the "Bernstein dimension" and "multiplicity," are invariants of the module. Those modules of minimal Bernstein dimension are our F-holonomic modules. We prove that all of Lyubeznik's unit F-modules belong to this category. The multiplicity, a completely new invariant for F-modules, behaves in some rather unexpected ways, compared to multiplicities in D-module theory.


    In order to construct our theory of F-holonomic F-modules, we had to develop novel Gr?bner basis techniques for Frobenius actions. This involved developing a new term order for Frobenius monomials, finding a generalization of Buchberger's algorithm for F-modules, and proving certain termination statements for that algorithm. We hope that our Gr?bner basis methods will contribute to advances in computations involving F-module theory.


    The PI has presented the results of this project at several conferences and seminars. The PI has also contributed to the mentorship of undergraduate students at the host institution, both formally as a mentor on a senior thesis project, and informally through office hours and outside of class discussions with students. The project has contributed significantly to the professional development of the PI as a mathematician, providing her the opportunity to undertake a very open-ended research project that started in a highly speculative state, and ended with a concrete fleshed-out theory, including theorems on computation.
